messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Hamon description
messages.msgSnippet: Yeah, except the nukeru part. That is not the right verb, I think. Gordon ... From: Richard Turner [mailto:ikkanshi@westnet.com.au] Sent: Saturday, July 24,
messages.messageBody:
Yeah, except the nukeru part. That is not the right verb, I think.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Richard Turner [mailto:ikkanshi@...]
Sent: Saturday, July 24, 2004 9:53 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Hamon description



Gordon, would it be Ashi hasaka e nukeru ?.

Rich

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Hamon description
messages.msgSnippet: Wonderful sword. Gordon ... From: Ron Hartmann [mailto:swords@usroute66.net] Sent: Saturday, July 24, 2004 9:40 AM To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com Subject:
messages.messageBody:
Wonderful sword.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Ron Hartmann [mailto:swords@...]
Sent: Saturday, July 24, 2004 9:40 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Hamon description



Thanks Gordon, I've not heard that one before. This is on the Jirotaro
Naokatsu you saw when you visited here a couple years back.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Gordon Robson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, July 23, 2004 7:28 PM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Hamon description


Hi Ron,



Its an nagai-ashi gunome. There is another description the would be
translated as "the long ashi approach the ha," but the exact Japanese
wording escapes me at the moment.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Ron Hartmann [mailto:swords@...]
Sent: Saturday, July 24, 2004 9:12 AM
To: TOKEN; nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Hamon description



Hi all -

A very small attachment shows what I've asked about. Hope it clears okay.
If
not, ask and I'll send it individually to anyone interested.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Gordon Robson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, July 23, 2004 6:29 PM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Hamon description


Hi Ron,



Hako-midare, ko-ashi hataraku might be closer, but a picture would help.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Ron Hartmann [mailto:swords@...]
Sent: Saturday, July 24, 2004 1:25 AM
To: TOKEN; nihontostudy; nihonto@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Hamon description



Curious about the correct way to describe a particular style of hamon
which
I'd describe as a smallish gunome with ko-ashi, in groups of five or six
gunome. Each section of gunome is seperated with a slightly larger ashi,
which while subtle, does make the straight gunmome hamon appear in
"groups"
of gunome. Hope that is clear.

One term I find is called "sugu ashi iri" which I take to mean, "suguha
containing ashi."

The pattern I'm trying to describe would see (to me) correctly described
as
something like "sugu kaku (boxed) gunome ashi iri" or am I sounding too
midwestern with my Japanese?? Any comments? If a small sketch (file)
would
help, I'll send one out.

Ron
STL

Curious about the correct way to describe a particular style of hamon

I'd describe as a smallish gunome with ko-ashi, in groups of five or six
gunome. Each section of gunome is seperated with a slightly larger ashi,

One term I find is called "sugu ashi iri" which I take to mean, "suguha

The pattern I'm trying to describe would see (to me) correctly described

midwestern with my Japanese?? Any comments? If a small sketch (file)
would
help, I'll send one out.

Ron

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Hamon description
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Ron, Its an nagai-ashi gunome. There is another description the would be translated as the long ashi approach the ha, but the exact Japanese wording
messages.messageBody:
Hi Ron,



Its an nagai-ashi gunome. There is another description the would be
translated as "the long ashi approach the ha," but the exact Japanese
wording escapes me at the moment.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Ron Hartmann [mailto:swords@...]
Sent: Saturday, July 24, 2004 9:12 AM
To: TOKEN; nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Hamon description



Hi all -

A very small attachment shows what I've asked about. Hope it clears okay. If
not, ask and I'll send it individually to anyone interested.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Gordon Robson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, July 23, 2004 6:29 PM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Hamon description


Hi Ron,



Hako-midare, ko-ashi hataraku might be closer, but a picture would help.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Ron Hartmann [mailto:swords@...]
Sent: Saturday, July 24, 2004 1:25 AM
To: TOKEN; nihontostudy; nihonto@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Hamon description



Curious about the correct way to describe a particular style of hamon
which
I'd describe as a smallish gunome with ko-ashi, in groups of five or six
gunome. Each section of gunome is seperated with a slightly larger ashi,
which while subtle, does make the straight gunmome hamon appear in
"groups"
of gunome. Hope that is clear.

One term I find is called "sugu ashi iri" which I take to mean, "suguha
containing ashi."

The pattern I'm trying to describe would see (to me) correctly described
as
something like "sugu kaku (boxed) gunome ashi iri" or am I sounding too
midwestern with my Japanese?? Any comments? If a small sketch (file)
would
help, I'll send one out.

Ron
STL

messages.subject: Hamon description
messages.msgSnippet: Curious about the correct way to describe a particular style of hamon which I d describe as a smallish gunome with ko-ashi, in groups of five or six gunome.
messages.messageBody:
Curious about the correct way to describe a particular style of hamon which I'd describe as a smallish gunome with ko-ashi, in groups of five or six gunome. Each section of gunome is seperated with a slightly larger ashi, which while subtle, does make the straight gunmome hamon appear in "groups" of gunome. Hope that is clear.

One term I find is called "sugu ashi iri" which I take to mean, "suguha containing ashi."

The pattern I'm trying to describe would see (to me) correctly described as something like "sugu kaku (boxed) gunome ashi iri" or am I sounding too midwestern with my Japanese?? Any comments? If a small sketch (file) would help, I'll send one out.

Ron
STL

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
